name: ğŸ“š A storybook you read at home
explanation: A printed storybook is just paper with ink. It doesn't learn, change, or respond to you - the words stay the same every time you read it.

name: ğŸ¤– Robot vacuum cleaner that moves by itself and senses objects
explanation: Robot vacuums use AI to map your home, avoid obstacles, and figure out the best path to clean every spot without getting stuck.

name: ğŸ”Š Voice on a smart speaker answering questions
explanation: Smart speakers like Alexa and Google Home use AI to understand your voice, figure out what you're asking, and find the right answer.

name: ğŸ® A video game character that responds to your playing style
explanation: Some video games use AI to make characters smarter. They learn your playing style and adapt to make the game more challenging or fun.

name: ğŸ“º Automatic captions on YouTube videos
explanation: YouTube uses AI called speech recognition to listen to videos and automatically write out what people are saying as text captions.

name: ğŸ“² Phone unlocking with your face
explanation: Face unlock uses AI to recognise your unique facial features. It can tell the difference between you and other people, or even a photo of you!

name: ğŸŒ Translation app that listens and speaks in another language
explanation: Translation apps use AI to understand speech in one language and convert it to another. They learn from millions of translated sentences.

name: ğŸš² A bicycle you ride to school
explanation: A bicycle is powered by you! It uses simple machines like gears, chains, and wheels - no computer brain needed.

name: ğŸ A toaster that browns bread
explanation: A toaster uses a simple timer and heating element. It doesn't learn or think - it just heats up for the time you set.

name: ğŸ“» A radio that plays music when you turn it on
explanation: A basic radio receives signals from radio stations and converts them to sound. It doesn't make decisions or learn your preferences.

name: ğŸ“º A regular TV remote
explanation: A TV remote just sends simple signals to your TV when you press buttons. It doesn't understand or learn anything.

name: ğŸ“· A printed photo album
explanation: A photo album is just printed pictures in a book. Unlike phone photos apps, it can't recognise faces or organise pictures automatically.

name: ğŸ”¦ A flashlight that turns on with a switch
explanation: A flashlight is a simple circuit - flip the switch, and electricity flows to make light. No thinking involved!

name: ğŸ•°ï¸ A clock with hands that tick
explanation: An analog clock uses gears and springs (or a small motor) to move the hands. It tells time through mechanical movement, not intelligence.
